content.text: Show that the average thickness of the wire is about \(0.2 \text{cm}\)
average thickness of wire = .........\(cm\)
The student's measurement of \(3.8 \text{cm}\) is inaccurate
Suggest one reason why the measurement is inaccurate
A student measures the length of the coil using a ruler. His measurement is \(3.8 \text{cm}\)
There are 20 turns of wire in the coil. The student uses his measurement to calculate the average thickness of the wire
The volume of the wire in the coil is \(16.6 \text{cm}^3\) and its mass is \(148 \text{g}\)
Calculate the density of the metal used for the wire in the coil
density = .........\(g / \text{cm}^3\)
The student has a measuring cylinder and a beaker of water, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Describe how the student can determine the volume of the coil by using the equipment shown in Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.1 shows a coil of wire
Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)
the length of the spring without a load
the length of the spring with a load of 4.0 N
the extension due to a 4.0 N load
extension = .........\(cm\)
A student stretches a spring by adding different loads to it. She measures the length of the spring for each load. She plots a graph of the results
Use the graph to determine:
Complete the sentence about effects of forces. Choose words from the box
Stretching a spring with a load is an example of how a force can change the
Describe the movement of the gas molecules
Describe how the molecules exert a pressure on the walls of the box
The gas in Fig. 3.1 is cooled. The gas turns into a liquid then into a solid
State how the average separation of molecules in the gas is different from the average separation of molecules in the solid
Some gas molecules are in a box at room temperature
Fig. 3.1 shows the position of some of the molecules and the direction of movement of each molecule
During part of a race, a skier travels a distance of \(200 \text{m}\) in a time of \(6.4 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average speed of the skier
average speed = .........\(m/s\)
Fig. 4.1 shows a speedâ€“time graph for the skier in another part of the race
Describe the motion of the skier at each point \(\mathbf{P}\) , \(\mathbf{Q}\) , \(\mathbf{R}\) and \(\mathbf{S}\) on the graph
P
Q
R
S
Skis are strapped to a skier's feet and are longer and wider than the skier's feet
Explain how the skis prevent the skier from sinking into soft snow
Show that the moment of the \(5.0 \text{N}\) force about the pivot is \(200 \text{N} \text{cm}\)
Calculate the size of force F
A metre rule is balanced on a pivot by three vertical forces, as shown in Fig. 5.1
This thermometer is used for measuring temperatures in science experiments
State the unit for measuring temperature
On Fig. 6.1, an arrow points to the temperature reading when the thermometer is placed in pure melting ice. This is labelled **ice point**
On Fig. 6.1, draw an arrow pointing to the temperature reading when the thermometer is at the upper fixed point. Label this arrow **steam point**
A liquid-in-glass thermometer uses the property of expansion of a liquid to measure temperature
State **one** other application or consequence of thermal expansion
The student turns on the radiant heater and starts a stop-clock. The wax on the plate with a dull black side melts and the metal disc falls off the plate 53 seconds after the stop-clock is started
The metal disc on the plate with a shiny metal side remains attached for another 32 seconds after the metal disc on the first plate falls
Explain why the metal disc on the plate with a dull black side falls before the metal disc on the plate with a shiny metal side
Another student observes the experiment shown in Fig. 6.2 and says that the comparison of the two plates is not fair
Suggest why the experiment is not fair
A student is testing how different surfaces absorb radiant heat

The student puts two metal plates in holders and places them on either side of a radiant heater as shown in Fig. 6.2. One plate has a shiny metal side facing towards the heater and the other plate has a dull black side facing towards the heater
A metal disc is attached to each plate using wax
Fig. 6.1 shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer
Determine the value of the angle of incidence for the ray of light at point P
angle of incidence = .........Â°
On Fig. 7.1,
* draw a normal at point P
* draw the ray reflected at point P
* determine the angle of reflection at point P
angle of reflection = .........Â°
Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of light striking a plane mirror at point P
Fig. 7.2 shows an object OB positioned \(20 \text{cm}\) from a thin converging lens. Both principal focuses of the lens are labelled F
Two rays from the tip B of the object are incident on the lens, as shown in Fig. 7.2
On Fig. 7.2, continue the paths of these two rays to show the position of the image of OB formed by the lens. Draw an arrow to show the size, position and orientation of the image of OB
Determine the wavelength of the sound wave
wavelength of the sound wave = .........\(cm\)
On Fig. 8.1, draw a wave representing a louder sound of the same wavelength
State the range of audible frequencies for a healthy human ear. Include the unit
Fig. 8.1 represents the pressure at one instant along part of a sound wave
On Fig. 9.1, write the letters N and S to indicate the north and south poles of the magnet
Fig. 9.2 shows a soft-iron bar placed close to a permanent magnet
State and explain what happens to the soft-iron bar. You may draw on Fig. 9.2
Fig. 9.1 shows the magnetic field pattern around a bar magnet
Ball P is negatively charged
State the charge on ball Q and the charge on ball R
ball Q
ball R
Explain your answer for part (i) for the charge on ball Q
Three balls P, Q and R are electrically charged. The balls are suspended by threads of insulating material. Fig. 9.3 shows the arrangement

The student uses the circuit to measure the resistance of component Y
Complete the diagram in Fig. 10.1 by adding electrical symbols to show an ammeter and a voltmeter correctly connected to determine the resistance of component Y
A student investigates the electrical resistance of some components
Fig. 10.1 shows an incomplete diagram of the circuit used by the student
Resistor A and resistor B are connected in series
State the value of their combined resistance
Resistor A and resistor B are connected in parallel
Compare the combined resistance when in parallel with the resistance of resistor A alone
Fig. 10.2 shows two resistors A and B
Draw the electrical symbol for a fuse
The metal case of the power supply is earthed. A fault occurs and a live wire touches the metal case
Explain how earthing the metal case protects the teacher
The power supply circuit includes a transformer. Its input voltage is \(240\mathrm{V}\). There are 960 turns on the input coil and 64 turns on the output coil
Calculate the output voltage of the transformer
output voltage = .........V
A teacher uses a power supply in a metal case. The circuit for the power supply includes a fuse
State which of these types of radiation can pass through paper
Barium-137 is a radioactive isotope. The nuclide notation for barium-137 is
Determine the number of neutrons in a nucleus of barium-137
number of neutrons = .........
An isotope of barium-137 has a half-life of 3 minutes
A radioactive source contains \(36\mathrm{mg}\) of this isotope
Calculate the mass of the isotope that remains in the source after 9 minutes
mass of the isotope remaining = .........mg
Radioactive sources emit \(\alpha\) -(alpha), \(\beta\) -(beta) and \(\gamma\) -(gamma) radiations
